entries: Questa è una puntata piuttosto speciale della serie Plane Shift per me, perché sono stato il capo creativo per la costruzione del mondo di Ixalan. Forse tradendo i miei quattordici anni di lavoro su Dungeons & Dragons, Ixalan è un mondo di esplorazione e di tesori, segnato da antichi siti che aspettano di essere esplorati da intrepidi eroi. Uno di questi siti, mostrato su una carta nel set di Ixalan, è ovviamente ispirato a un'avventura classica di D&D, The Hidden Shrine of Tamoachan. A questo piano mancano solo i draghi per essere un ambiente di D&D pienamente realizzato - c'è persino una mappa del mondo! In definitiva, ciò significa che scrivere Plane Shift: Ixalan è stato sia una tonnellata di divertimento che relativamente facile. Le persone che popolano Ixalan hanno già molto in comune con i personaggi di D&D, e mapparle con le classi e i background esistenti è stato un compito piuttosto semplice. Allo stesso modo, le creature del piano - specialmente i dinosauri - avevano già molti analoghi nel gioco. E ancora, questa è la più lunga puntata di Plane Shift finora! Questo in parte perché ho avuto la libertà di dare libero sfogo alle idee e all'ispirazione per aiutarvi a giocare un personaggio in questo eccitante mondo. Qui troverete più tabelle che mai: tabelle di tratti di personalità e ideali per dare corpo al vostro personaggio, di tesori per insaporire le vostre scorte e di ispirazione per mettere insieme il vostro gruppo. Questo genere di cose è allo stesso tempo molto divertente e molto impegnativo da scrivere - molto simile al testo dei sapori sulle carte di Magic, in realtà, perché ognuno è una pepita autocontenuta, un'idea completa in una sola frase. Spero che tutta questa roba arricchisca il vostro gioco. L'appendice di questo documento è una lunga riflessione sui colori di Magic e la loro relazione con i personaggi e gli incantesimi di D&D. Questo è il genere di cose che domina molte conversazioni all'ora di pranzo con i membri del team creativo di Magic che sono anche avidi fan di D&D, e anche il genere di cose su cui ricevo molte domande su Twitter. Come per gran parte del resto di questo documento, l'attenzione è più sul gioco di ruolo e sulla costruzione del personaggio che sulle regole. È una prima pugnalata, però, verso una comprensione più completa della relazione tra i mondi di entrambi i giochi. Come sempre, The Art of Magic: The Gathering-Ixalan è la risorsa definitiva per le informazioni sul piano. Con questo documento, potete usare quelle informazioni per costruire una campagna con un minimo di modifiche alle regole della quinta edizione di D&D, che potete trovare qui. E anche senza il libro, potete trovare il lore su Ixalan sul sito web di Magic. C'è un sacco di spazio aperto su quella mappa. Spero che vi divertiate ad esplorare il mondo di Ixalan!

data.name: Sun Empire
entries: L'Impero del Sole è una potente civiltà che domina la costa orientale di Ixalan. I feroci guerrieri dell'impero sono supportati da sacerdoti che esercitano il potere del sole e comandano i potenti dinosauri che abitano il continente. Un nuovo sovrano ha portato l'impero in un'era di espansione, cercando di reclamare le terre dell'interno del continente che un tempo deteneva. Allo stesso tempo, un'incursione straniera in quelle stesse terre scatena la ricerca dell'artefatto conosciuto come il Sole Immortale, che il popolo dell'impero vede come un potente simbolo della propria identità.

items.name: Races:
entries: {@race Human}

items.name: Suggested Backgrounds:
entries: {@background Acolyte}, {@background entertainer}, {@background folk hero}, {@background guild artisan}, {@background hermit}, {@background noble}, {@background sage}, {@background soldier}, {@background urchin}

entries.name: Suggested Classes
entries: Considera le seguenti opzioni di classe per il tuo personaggio di Sun Empire.

entries.name: {@class Barbarian}
entries: Alcuni guerrieri devoti a Tilonalli (l'aspetto distruttivo del Triplice Sole, la divinità adorata dal popolo dell'impero) entrano in collera durante il combattimento. La Via del Berserker è appropriata per questi personaggi, o la Via del Guerriero Totem (sostituendo gli spiriti totem dell'orso, dell'aquila e del lupo con quelli del ceratopo, dell'aerosauro e del raptor, rispettivamente).

entries.name: {@class Bard}
entries: La poesia è un'arte rispettata tra i guerrieri dell'Impero del Sole, quindi i bardi del Collegio del Valore potrebbero essere trovati tra le loro fila.

entries.name: {@class Cleric}
entries: I chierici dell'Impero del Sole sono tipicamente devoti a un particolare aspetto del Triplice Sole. Kinjalli, il Sole del Risveglio, rappresenta gli aspetti creativi della divinità e garantisce l'accesso ai domini della Vita e della Luce. Ixalli, il Sole Verdeggiante, rappresenta i suoi aspetti di sostegno e di nutrimento, garantendo l'accesso ai domini della Vita e del {@skill Nature}. Tilonalli, il Sole Ardente, rappresenta i suoi aspetti distruttivi e dà accesso ai domini della Tempesta e della Guerra.

entries.name: {@class Druid}
entries: Alcuni sciamani dell'Impero del Sole sono strettamente in sintonia con le forze della natura, e usano la forma selvaggia per assumere forme di dinosauri. Questi druidi seguono tipicamente il Circolo della Luna.

entries.name: {@class Fighter}
entries: I soldati e i guerrieri altamente addestrati sono la spina dorsale dell'Impero del Sole. Sono tipicamente Maestri di Battaglia o Campioni.

entries.name: {@class Paladin}
entries: I cavalieri dell'Impero del Sole sono attratti dal Giuramento degli Antichi e (sempre più spesso, dato che vampiri e pirati fanno incursioni nelle loro terre) dal Giuramento della Vendetta. Questi paladini usano spesso l'incantesimo {@spell find steed} per acquisire cavalcature di dinosauri (tipicamente un adrosauro, descritto nella Guida ai Mostri di Volo).

entries.name: {@class Ranger}
entries: Gli esploratori dell'Impero del Sole sono spesso ranger, compresi sia i Beast Master che i Cacciatori. Lo pteranodonte, il dimetrodonte e il velociraptor sono tutti compagni appropriati dei ranger.

entries.name: Four Peoples, One Party
entries: La cosa più difficile nel giocare a D&D in un'ambientazione altamente fazionalizzata come Ixalan è mettere insieme personaggi che appartengono a gruppi diversi e che non hanno alcun motivo ovvio per voler cooperare, figuriamoci per fidarsi l'uno dell'altro. Una possibilità, naturalmente, è che tutti i personaggi appartengano alla stessa fazione. Un gruppo di soli vampiri che si dedica alla conquista o un gruppo di soli pirati che vuole esplorare il mare di Stormwreck può trovare molta avventura in Ixalan. Ma se un giocatore è intenzionato a interpretare un merfolk e uno è determinato ad essere un orco, è necessario qualche sforzo in più per metterli insieme.

L'approccio più diretto è quello di mettere i personaggi in una situazione in cui hanno bisogno di lavorare insieme per sopravvivere o per raggiungere qualche obiettivo che tutti condividono. La necessità fa strani compagni di letto, come dice il proverbio, e i personaggi che si trovano in una brutta situazione hanno un forte incentivo a mettere da parte le loro differenze e lavorare insieme, almeno fino a quando non escono da quella situazione. Potrebbero essere tutti intrappolati nello stesso posto, o ogni personaggio potrebbe avere qualcosa di cui tutto il gruppo ha bisogno.

Puoi tirare sulla seguente tabella per generare idee per far incontrare i personaggi all'inizio della campagna. Idealmente, quando avranno superato qualsiasi circostanza li abbia fatti incontrare, avranno imparato a fidarsi l'uno dell'altro e forse anche a diventare amici.

rows: I personaggi iniziano la campagna catturati, come prigionieri della Legione del Crepuscolo, prigionieri nel brigantino di una nave pirata o intrappolati nelle trappole della giungla.
I personaggi stanno combattendo tra loro quando un dinosauro attacca.
I personaggi sono intrappolati insieme da un crollo, dall'apertura di una voragine o da qualche disastro simile.
Ogni personaggio ha un pezzo di una mappa del tesoro, o una chiave tra le varie necessarie per aprire una cassaforte.
Uno strano sogno conduce ciascuno dei personaggi alla stessa destinazione.
I personaggi sono tutti irrimediabilmente persi nella giungla.
I leader delle fazioni dei personaggi hanno ordinato loro di cooperare in una missione segreta.
Un capitano pirata o un altro cattivo è un nemico comune a tutti i personaggi.
Un fenomeno magico o naturale minaccia tutti gli abitanti di Ixalan.
Tutti i personaggi cercano di evitare la catastrofe di una guerra su vasta scala tra i loro popoli.

entries.caption: Suggested Ideals
rows: {@b Nation.} Gli invasori devono essere cacciati e l'antica capitale di Orazca deve essere recuperata.
{@b Glory.} Desidero guadagnare grande gloria in battaglia - idealmente, facendo arrendere i miei nemici.
{@b Poetry.} La bellezza si trova in tutte le cose, dalla creazione alla distruzione, e dovrebbe essere registrata nelle parole.
{@b Zeal.} Sono devoto al Triplice Sole e ai comandi dei sacerdoti.
{@b History.} Cerco di capire la storia dell'impero per poter tracciare meglio la rotta per il suo futuro.
{@b Peace.} Vorrei credere che la pace possa essere forgiata tra i popoli di questa terra.

entries.caption: Suggested Bonds
rows: Ho lasciato una famiglia (viva o morta) quando ho iniziato il mio viaggio di esplorazione.
Ho legami con la linea imperiale.
Vengo da una famiglia nobile e ho dei parenti che vivono come ostaggi nella capitale imperiale.
Mi sono innamorato di un membro di un equipaggio di pirati.
Ho scoperto un'antica rovina nella giungla, ma la tengo segreta.
Un giorno troverò il Sole Immortale e restaurerò l'antica gloria dell'impero

entries.name: Languages
entries: Generalmente, in una campagna di D&D, è una buona idea assicurarsi che tutti i personaggi dei giocatori possano capirsi. Ecco perché il gioco mantiene la comoda finzione di una lingua comune. Ma Ixalan riguarda lo scontro di quattro culture, quindi potreste voler enfatizzare le differenze tra queste culture facendo parlare ai personaggi di ciascuna di esse lingue completamente diverse.

Se si segue questa strada, Merfolk è la lingua degli Araldi del Fiume e Vampiro è la lingua della Legione del Crepuscolo. Gli umani dell'Impero del Sole parlano la loro lingua, l'Itzocan, e gli umani della Brazen Coalition parlano un'altra lingua - un pidgin di Orco, Sirena e una lingua umana nativa che è simile al Vampiro (tanto simile all'italiano quanto allo spagnolo). Anche gli orchi, le sirene e i goblin parlano questo pidgin della Brazen Coalition.

Si potrebbe ancora voler ammettere l'esistenza di una sorta di pidgin comune utilizzato in circostanze in cui i membri di popoli diversi interagiscono tra loro. Ma una tale lingua è quasi impossibile da usare per discussioni su questioni di una certa profondità.

entries.name: River Heralds
entries: The River Heralds are a collection of small, nomadic bands of merfolk who were the dominant inhabitants of Ixalan before the rise of the Sun Empire. They live in harmony with the land, and their shamans wield powerful nature magic to control the elements of wind and water. They believe that the power of the Immortal Sun is too dangerous for anyone to wield—including themselves. And so they seek to protect the golden city of Orazca and steer all intruders away from it.

items.name: Races:
entries: {@race Merfolk (Ixalan)|PSX}

items.name: Suggested Backgrounds:
entries: {@background Acolyte}, {@background folk hero}, {@background hermit}, {@background outlander}, {@background sage}

entries.name: Suggested Classes
entries: Consider the following class options for your River Herald character.

entries.name: {@class Druid}
entries: Many River Herald shamans are druids of the Circle of the Land.

entries.name: {@class Fighter}
entries: The warriors among the River Heralds include cunning strategists (often Battle Masters), bold Champions, and Eldritch Knights who fuse arcane magic with their use of weapons.

entries.name: {@class Ranger}
entries: Other River Herald warriors wield the druidic magic of the forest in the defense of their lands. Wizard. The magic of wind, mist, illusion, and misdirection is the province of River Herald wizards.

entries.name: {@class Wizard}
entries: The magic of wind, mist, illusion, and misdirection is the province of River Herald wizards.

entries.caption: Suggested Ideals
rows: {@b Harmony.}. The peoples of this world should strive for the same harmony that exists between air and water.
{@b  Nature.} In the midst of war, it is often the forest that suffers most—unless we protect it.
{@b  Knowledge.} True understanding of one's self and the world is the highest good.
{@b Reverence.} The wisdom of the shamans and elders is our best guide in the world.
{@b  Cleverness.} The best way to defeat your opponents is to outsmart them.
{@b  Defense.} The golden city must remain hidden, and its power kept from those who would abuse it.

entries.caption: Suggested Bonds
rows: I have carried on secret trade with a Sun Empire merchant for years now.
I am related to the shaman of my band.
I am fascinated by the culture and beliefs of the strangers in our land.
A small tributary to the Great River is in my care, and I will do anything to defend it.
I aspire to become the leader of my band—either as a shaman, or by supplanting the shaman as a war leader.
I will one day find the Immortal Sun and use its power to drive the invaders from our land.

entries.name: Legion of Dusk
entries: The society of the Legion of Dusk is built around the rites and devotion of a powerful church, led by undead paladins who sustain themselves on the blood of their enemies. After seven hundred years of war that saw them march across the entirety of their home continent, the vampires of the Legion have come to add Ixalan to their territory. Certain leaders among them also seek the Immortal Sun, which is dimly remembered in their own legends as a source of true immortality—eternal life, in contrast to the endless undeath they now endure.

items.name: Races:
entries: {@race Vampire (Ixalan)|PSX}, {@race Human (Ixalan)|PSX}

items.name: Suggested Backgrounds:
entries: {@background Acolyte}, {@background noble}, {@background sage}, {@background soldier}, {@background urchin} (human only)

entries.name: Suggested Classes
entries: Consider the following class options for your Legion of Dusk character.

entries.name: {@class Cleric}
entries: Clerics of the Church of Dusk typically choose the Death, Life, or War domains.

entries.name: {@class Fighter}
entries: The bulk of the Legion of Dusk is made up of soldiers and knights, who might be Battle Masters or Champions.

entries.name: {@class Monk}
entries: Certain vampire clerics live under strict rules of fasting, prayer, and martial discipline, and might be considered monks of the Way of the Open Hand or the Way of Shadow. The latter often act as agents for Queen Miralda, who rules the Legion of Dusk with an iron hand.

entries.name: {@class Paladin}
entries: Vampire paladins of the Legion of Dusk typically swear the Oath of Devotion, though the tenets they follow are appropriate to their particular faith. (If you are using Xanathar's Guide to Everything, the Oath of Conquest is even more appropriate.)

entries.caption: Suggested Ideals
rows: {@b Conquest.} The destiny of my people is to rule the world.
{@b Order.} The purpose of our conquest is to establish law and order in the lands we rule.
{@b Devotion.} Following the tenets of the church is the only way to earn eternal life in the coming age of ever-flowing blood.
{@b Slaughter.} I love the feeling of warm blood running down my chin.
{@b Glory.} Those who prove their worth in battle will win eternal life.
Strength. In life as in war, the stronger force wins.

entries.caption: Suggested Bonds
rows: My family has been feuding with another noble family for seven hundred years.
I became friends with a merfolk shaman I captured.
I am a knight of the Bloodstained order, and have forsaken all other bonds since the day I slaughtered my own family.
I carry a relic of one of the vampire saints known as the Venerables, counting it as my dearest possession.
I would do anything for the soldiers in my company.
I will one day find the Immortal Sun and use its power to supplant the queen.

entries.name: Tenets of Blood
entries: The vampires of the Legion of Dusk can hardly be considered good, but they do favor law and a sense of honor. The tenets of the vampire paladins' oath reflect that view.

entries.name: Honesty
entries: Don't demean yourself with lying and cheating. Don't make promises you can't keep.

entries.name: Courage
entries: Never let a foe see your fear.

entries.name: Honor
entries: Treat your peers with fairness and your lessers with exactly what they deserve. Those who recognize your position deserve at least a modicum of respect.

entries.name: Duty
entries: Your actions should serve the aims of the queen and the church, and not bring dishonor to either. Take responsibility for your actions and their consequences, and obey your superiors.

entries.name: Brazen Coalition
entries: The Brazen Coalition was formed by sailors who fled across the sea, escaping the final advance of the Legion of Dusk against the Free Cities of Torrezon. These mariners originally sought to establish colonies on Ixalan and trade with the cities of the Sun Empire. But when the Sun Empire drove them off, they turned instead to piracy and plunder. The Brazen Coalition has since become a loosely affiliated group of pirate captains who seek to rule the seas and claim the riches of Ixalan—especially the Immortal Sun.

items.name: Races:
entries: {@race Goblin (Ixalan)|PSX}, {@race Human (Ixalan)|PSX}, {@race Orc (Ixalan)|PSX}, {@race Siren|PSX}

items.name: Suggested Backgrounds:
entries: {@background Charlatan}, {@background criminal}, {@background entertainer}, {@background folk hero}, {@background sage}, {@background sailor}

entries.name: Suggested Classes
entries: Consider the following class options for your Brazen Coalition character.

entries.name: {@class Bard}
entries: Sirens are frequently bards, and other pirates (especially in Captain Parrish's Deadeye fleet) collect knowledge as members of the College of Lore.

entries.name: {@class Fighter}
entries: A great many pirates are fighters, including not just Champions and Battlemasters, but also Eldritch Knights who combine martial skill with the magical talents common in the Coalition.

entries.name: {@class Rogue}
entries: Scoundrels, swashbucklers, thieves, and killers make up the majority of the Brazen Coalition.

entries.name: {@class Warlock}
entries: Of all the peoples of Ixalan, the pirates of the Dire Fleet are most likely to traffic with demons. Many of its sailors become warlocks as a result of striking bargains with the Fiend.

entries.name: {@class Wizard}
entries: Orc wizards use fire and necromantic magic, sirens are fond of enchantments, and humans employ a variety of magical talents, including the invention of magic items.

entries.caption: Suggested Ideals
rows: {@b Wealth.} Money can buy anything.
{@b Freedom.} The sea is the freedom to go anywhere and do anything.
{@b Knowledge.} I'm as greedy for secrets and lore as others are for treasure.
{@b Pillage.} It's not the having, it's the taking that shows who's strongest.
{@b Crew.} I'm committed to my crewmates, not to ideals.
{@b Coalition.} I believe we're not just stronger but also better when we join forces in unity.

entries.caption: Suggested Bonds
rows: My captain is dearer to me than any other person or possession.
My greatest dream is to return across the sea to the land my ancestors left.
I abandoned a child to be fostered in a city somewhere.
I was shipwrecked on an island with a vampire, and we became good friends.
I buried a great treasure somewhere. . . and lost the map.
I have one piece of a treasure map, and no idea where the other pieces are.

data.name: Land of the Great River
entries: The center of the world is the great continent known as Ixalan, which has given its name to the plane as a whole. A tropical land covered in lush rain forest, soaring mountains, lofty plains, and winding rivers, Ixalan is shaped like a large crescent enfolding a vast inner sea. Its history has been shaped by the interaction between the Sun Empire and the River Heralds. Both peoples lived in balance while the Sun Empire maintained its stewardship of the Immortal Sun. But that balance was upset when the emperor abused the artifact's power. Now the Sun Empire has been pushed to the coastal lands of Ixalan, while the River Heralds dominate the interior.

entries.name: Ancient Sites
entries: The Sun Empire was once larger than it presently is, and remnants of its past glory still lie scattered throughout the jungles of the Great River. Some of these remnants are no more than heaps of rubble overgrown by hardy plant life, potentially interesting for the sake of inscriptions that might remain on worn stone surfaces, but otherwise remarkable only as landmarks for those traveling through the uncharted wilderness. However, several whole cities also lie in ruins scattered throughout the jungle.

Quetzatl was once the home of a self-proclaimed king who challenged the authority of the emperor. Its ruins betray the violence used to tear its buildings down stone by stone, and legend holds that spirits of the dead, including the Pretender King, still haunt those ruins.

The city of Pecatli was known for its grand temple, which boasted three great spires for the three aspects of the sun. The spires have long been toppled, but the diamonds, emeralds, and rubies said to have crowned them have never been found.

Techepec was a retreat for the emperor and the imperial family, a place where they could escape the trials of life at court for a time. In fact, Emperor Huatzan II used Techepec as a sort of capital-in-exile during a brief period of insurrection, when another pretender sat on the throne in Orazca.

Azcanta, now called the Sunken Ruin, was a thriving population center until a prolonged conflict with the River Heralds caused it to sink into the waters of the Inner Sea. Its buildings are still largely intact far beneath the waves, and some pirates now seek the city's treasures.

A few lone shrines and temples dot the jungle as well, the last remnants of cities whose wooden buildings have long since rotted away. These include Tonalixco, the temple of the eastern sun, which marked the western edge of the empire in the fortress-city of Tanaztac. Icalaquiampa, the temple of sunset, was the focus of a religious sect that tried to replace the emperor with a high priest and establish theocratic rule.

Aclazotz was a temple dedicated to a bat god of the night, opposed to the Threefold Sun and the empire devoted to the sun. The temple makes an appearance in "X Marks the Spot," a special D&D Ixalan adventure created for Extra Life 2017, but there's much more to this legendary site. Aclazotz was partially inspired by the classic D&D adventure The Hidden Shrine of Tamoachan, which appears in updated form in Tales from the Yawning Portal. If you want to more fully explore the ruins, you might use that adventure as a starting point. Perhaps this is where Elenda, the knight who brought the rites of vampirism to the Legion of Dusk, underwent her own transformation.

Of course, the grandest ruin of the ancient Sun Empire is Orazca, the glorious golden city where the Immortal Sun still lies hidden. It was the empire's capital for many centuries, and tribute from across the breadth of Ixalan was brought to adorn its palaces and temples. Gold covers nearly every building in the city, and jade inlays reflect the influence of the ancient merfolk who shared Orazca with the humans of the empire. But the world has since closed up over the golden city, hiding its secrets and its treasures from all who seek it. Three golden spires are now the only visible signs of Orazca where they rise above the forest floor.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Treasure is an important part of adventuring in any Dungeons & Dragons campaign, and that is perhaps more true on Ixalan than on most planes in Magic's Multiverse. You can use cards (including Treasure tokens) as inspiration for the kinds of treasures that adventurers might find. When a treasure hoard includes art objects, you can use these tables to provide a distinctive flavor to Ixalan's treasures. (If you look closely, you'll see many of these objects in the art on Treasure token cards, reproduced on these pages.)

When adventurers discover magic items as treasure, you can use {@table Who Created It or Was Intended to Use It?|PSX|this table} in place of the one in chapter 7 of the Dungeon Master's Guide to determine the character of any particular magic item.

entries.name: Appendix: The Colors of Magic
entries: All the planes of Magic's Multiverse are suffused with mana—the energy that fuels magic in all its forms. Mana is intricately linked with the physical world, and different types of terrain produce different "colors" of mana. Most mages specialize in the use of one or perhaps two colors of mana, and in the particular types of magical effects that mana can create.

Color is a fundamental organizing principle of the Multiverse, closely linked with everything from physical geography to human personality. The following are just some of the correlations between color and other aspects of existence:

items.name: Lands:
items.entry: Different types of terrain generate mana of different colors. For example, mountains produce red mana,while plains produce white mana.

items.name: Philosophical Principles:
items.entry: Each color is associated with a set of ideals, values, and principles. White is connected with protection and order, and green with life and nature.

items.name: Magical Effects:
items.entry: Different colors of mana are used to power different kinds of spells. Spells of fire, lightning, and speed draw on red mana, while spells of water, ice, and the mind use blue mana.

items.name: Races and Creatures:
items.entry: Humans are exceptional, in that they don't have a particular aptitude or affinity for one color of mana. For other races, and even for nonsentient creatures, the connection is much stronger. Elves, for example, are typically green aligned. They use nature magic, and they value things like balance, stability, and interdependence. Hydras are also green aligned, though they don't use magic and they don't have values—even as they can be seen to embody those values. So if you wanted to summon a hydra, you'd use a green spell to do it.

items.name: Metaphysical Essence:
items.entry: Sometimes magic or even powerful emotions can change the basic nature of people or creatures in a way that alters their color alignment. A vile curse might change someone from green aligned to black aligned (or both green and black aligned). A terrible loss that spurs someone to vengeance might add red to the person's color alignment—temporarily or even permanently.

items.name: Personality Traits:
items.entry: Different colors of mana are associated with different qualities of personality. It might be that a person who is emotionally driven, creative, and energetic is naturally drawn to the use of red mana; or perhaps using red mana brings out those qualities in a person. Most likely, the effect runs both ways.

entries: A character's or creature's "color alignment" is a sort of shorthand that sketches out its personality, alignment, and power suite—the kinds of effects that it creates with its magic or through its behavior. This section goes over the traits of each of the five colors, and offers suggestions for ways they might influence a D&D character.

entries.name: Multiple Colors
entries: Many mages, especially Planeswalkers, routinely draw on two or more colors of mana. In some worlds, color pairs or triads have such a strong identity that they are manifested in the world. The guilds of Ravnica, for example, are each aligned to a specific pair of mana colors, and each of the clans of Tarkir used three colors. And some lands produce mana of more than one color, so that a highland lake might produce both red and blue mana. Mana pairs similarly suggest certain principles, create certain magical effects, and favor certain personality traits.

Based on the color wheel, it's possible to speak of two colors of mana as either "allied" (adjacent to each other on the wheel) or "enemy" (separated by another color). White's allied colors are green and blue; its enemy colors are red and black. That doesn't mean that creatures associated with allied colors are necessarily on the same side of any conflict, or that creatures associated with enemy colors are actually enemies. But if conflict does arise—for example, in a party of adventurers—it's more likely to arise between a whitealigned and a red-aligned character than between a white-aligned and a blue-aligned one. That's the natural result of the different personalities and principles associated with each color. A white character might put a lot of stress on the value of law and order, and of working together toward a common goal. A red-aligned character values freedom and individuality.

entries.name: Characters and Colors
entries: In the language of the D&D game, the colors of mana are a means of categorizing the types of magic that suffuse all existence. When a spellcaster draws upon or manipulates the Weave (see chapter 10 in the Player's Handbook), part of that process involves tugging on a strand that connects to a land that produces mana of the desired color. Whether consciously or unconsciously, a druid casting barkskin tugs on a strand of the Weave connected to a forest in the world, drawing out the green mana needed to cast the spell.

There's no rules weight to this material; it's simply about roleplaying your character. If you're playing a cleric, you might find it helpful to imagine your character drawing on white mana, and you'll find that a lot of your spells could indeed be white spells in Magic. You might also find inspiration in the personality traits and ideals described in the white mana entry. But there's no rule preventing your character from using spells like divination (a blue spell), stone shape (a red spell), create undead (a black spell), or insect plague (a green spell). On the other hand, you might find that thinking about your cleric as a white-aligned caster shapes your choice of spells as well as your personality.

entries.name: White
entries: Order. Protection. Community. White draws strength from groups working together, standing firm against the chaos that would divide them. The whole is greater than the sum of its parts, and safety is found in numbers. You can read a lot more about white {@link in this article|https://magic.wizards.com/en/articles/archive/making-magic/great-white-way-revisited-2015-07-13} by Mark Rosewater, Magic's head designer.

entries.caption: White Personality Traits
rows: I can find common ground with even the fiercest enemies, empathizing with them and always working toward peace.
I would rather make a new friend than a new enemy.
If someone is in trouble, I'm always ready to lend aid.
I get overly upset when people break even minor rules.
I am honest to the point of being blunt or rude.
I go into every situation with at least one backup plan, but I can get lost when my plans go awry.
I have no patience for selfish or greedy people.
I like my environment to be well ordered and clean.

entries.caption: White Ideals
rows: {@b Harmony.} I long for a world in which everyone gets along.
{@b Community.} It is the duty of all civilized people to strengthen the bonds of community and the security of civilization.
{@b Peace.} It is each person's responsibility to make the most happiness for the whole community.
{@b Solidarity.} Working together, we are stronger than any of us alone.
{@b Law and Order.} We all must obey those in authority and follow laws, or society will devolve into chaos.
{@b Honor.} If I dishonor myself, I undermine the foundation of my community.

entries.name: Color Combinations
entries: Adding blue to white steers it toward lawful neutral, creating archetypes such as the devout monk or the honorable paladin.
Adding black to white steers it toward lawful evil, exemplified by oppressive clerics and fallen paladins.
Adding red to white makes it zealously lawful good, as in the case of a fervent paladin.
Adding green to white steers it toward neutral good and gentler notions of community, embodied in characters such as healing druids, bards, or kindly rangers.

entries.name: Blue
entries: Wisdom. Contemplation. Manipulation. Blue's strength is the power of the mind—its limitless ability to imagine, invent, strategize, and deceive. Knowledge is power, and victory goes to the smarter foe.
More information about blue's philosophies and powers can be found {@link here|https://magic.wizards.com/en/articles/archive/making-magic/true-blue-revisited-2015-07-20}.

items.name: Power Suite:
items.entry: Control, the mind, counterspells, illusion, transformation, time, wind, water, and ice

items.name: Suggested Races:
items.entry: {@race Human}, {@race Merfolk (Ixalan)|PSX|merfolk}, {@race vedalken|GGR}, {@race aven|PSA}, {@race naga|PSA}, {@race siren|PSX}

entries.caption: Blue Personality Traits
rows: I employ a polysyllabic vocabulary that conveys the impression of tremendous erudition.
I'm used to helping out those who aren't as smart as I am, and I patiently explain anything and everything to others.
I often get lost in my own thoughts and contemplation, becoming oblivious to my surroundings.
I believe that anything worth doing is worth doing right. I can't help it—I'm a perfectionist.
I want to know how things work and what makes people act as they do.
There's nothing I like more than a good mystery.
Messing up just means an opportunity to learn from my mistakes.
There's no need to rush into action; I prefer to plan before I act.

entries.caption: Blue Ideals
rows: {@b Perfection.} The goal of a life of study is to constantly improve oneself.
{@b Education.} Information can change the world only when it is widely shared.
{@b Knowledge.} The path to power and self-improvement comes through mastery of what can be known.
{@b Change.} The world is in constant flux, and we must be ready to change with it.
{@b Logic.} Emotions must not cloud our clear thinking.
{@b Self-Knowledge.} If you know yourself, there's nothing left to know.

entries.name: Color Combinations
entries: Adding white to blue steers it toward lawful neutral, creating archetypes such as the devout monk or the honorable paladin.
Adding black to blue steers it toward neutral evil and the behavior of stealthy spies, scoundrels, and infiltrators.
Adding red to blue steers it toward chaotic neutral, exemplified by madcap mages—elementalist wizards or sorcerers.
Adding green to blue solidifies its neutrality, embodied in archetypes such as the sagacious druid or the scholar of nature.

entries.name: Black
entries: Ambition. Cruelty. Death. Black draws its power from the slow decay of all things and the inevitability of extinction. Supremacy belongs to those who are willing to do whatever it takes—including hastening death's arrival—to achieve their ends.
Mark Rosewater has written more about black {@link here|https://magic.wizards.com/en/articles/archive/making-magic/black-revisited-2015-07-27}.

items.name: Power Suite:
items.entry: Necromancy, fear, pain, darkness, disease, corruption

items.name: Suggested Races:
items.entry: {@race Human}, {@race Vampire (Ixalan)|PSX|vampire}, {@race aetherborn|PSK}, {@race minotaur|GGR}, {@race Vampire (Zendikar)|PSZ|vampire}, {@race Orc (Ixalan)|PSX|orc}

entries.caption: Black Personality Traits
rows: The best way to get me to do something is to tell me I can't do it. 2 If you do me an injury, I will crush you, ruin your name, and salt your family's lands for all time.
The first thing I do in a new place is note the locations of everything valuable—or where such things might be hidden.
I get bitter if I'm not the center of attention.
I can't stand the dangerous idiots who deny their own needs in order to help others. It's often difficult to motivate them to do what I want.
If others won't do things when you ask nicely, stop asking nicely.
Inspiring fear can be the most effective way to motivate people.
I don't care about morality or taboos—only results. I'll do whatever it takes to get the results I want.

entries.caption: Black Ideals
rows: {@b Power.} Power is the only way to guarantee your ability to control your life—and thus your happiness.
{@b Self-Interest.} If I don't look out for myself, no one else is going to.
Strength. Helping the weak is merely delaying their inevitable failure.
{@b Freedom.} If I need something, I'm a fool if I let laws or morality stand in my way.
{@b Greed.} The clearest way to get ahead in this world is with money.
{@b Independence.} No one tells me what to do.

entries.name: Color Combinations
entries: Adding white to black steers it toward lawful evil, exemplified by oppressive clerics and fallen paladins.

Adding blue to black steers it toward neutral evil and the behavior of stealthy spies, scoundrels, and infiltrators. Adding red to black creates the chaotic evil icons of bloodthirsty barbarians and battle priests.
Adding green to black steers it toward neutral evil, in the form of sinister druids and stalking rangers.

entries.name: Red
entries: Passion. Impulse. Immolation. Red values action over reflection, emotion over reason, and instinct over learning. Its power is the volatile energy of fire and lightning, the seismic energy of the earth, and the savagery of untamed fury.
{@link This article|https://magic.wizards.com/en/articles/archive/making-magic/seeing-red-revisited-2015-08-03} discusses the motivations and actions of red in more detail.

items.name: Power Suite:
items.entry: Fire and lightning, earth, emotion, rage, destruction

entries.caption: Red Personality Traits
rows: I always speak and act before I think.
My changing emotions dominate my personality, leaving no one in any doubt about what I'm feeling.
I fall in and out of love faster than the weather changes.
I'm always angry.
I either love something or I hate it; there is no in-between.
I'm always working on some piece of art to express my feelings.
I revel in the storms and the destruction that give expression to the turmoil inside me.
I have no patience for people who think they can boss others around.

entries.caption: Red Ideals
rows: {@b Freedom.} Everyone should be free to pursue their own dreams.
{@b Emotion.} My heart tells me what it needs. All I have to do is listen and act accordingly.
{@b Adventure.} Life is an adventure, and it's up to each individual to experience it.
{@b Relationships.} Part of life is embracing the passion, loyalty, and camaraderie that ties us to others.
{@b Creativity.} The world is in need of new ideas and bold action.
{@b Sincerity.} No one should pretend to be something they're not.

entries.name: Color Combinations
entries: Adding white to red makes it more zealously lawful good, as in the case of a fervent paladin.
Adding blue to red steers it toward chaotic neutral, exemplified by madcap mages—elementalist wizards or sorcerers.

Adding black to red creates the chaotic evil icons of bloodthirsty barbarians and battle priests. Adding green to red leads to an intense neutral or chaotic neutral, embodied in a totemic barbarian or fierce ranger.

entries.name: Green
entries: Nature's abundance. Lush growth. Vibrant life. Green knows that the artificial trappings of civilization are temporary but the vast ecosystems of nature will always endure—adapting and evolving in a delicate balance. Those who would prosper must also evolve, embracing their wild side and letting nature have its way.
Mark Rosewater's essay on the nature and philosophy of green can be found {@link here|http://magic.wizards.com/en/articles/archive/making-magic/its-not-easy-being-green-revisited-2015-08-10}.

entries.caption: Green Personality Traits
rows: I'm sharply attuned to the cycles of nature, and can almost feel the pull of the full moon.
My instincts never lead me astray.
I get along better with animals than I do with most people.
There is more wisdom in a forest pool than in any library.
Beasts of the wild have no need for manners, and neither do I.
Nothing raises my ire like seeing people treat life as disposable.
I can identify hundreds of bird species by their songs.
I see omens in every ripple, gust of wind, and flight of birds.

entries.caption: Green Ideals
rows: {@b Acceptance.} Things are as they are for a reason, and it's foolish to try to change them.
{@b Nature.} The natural world is more important than the constructs of civilization.
{@b Potential.} The secret to happiness is to find one's place in the natural order and embrace it.
{@b Interdependence.} My role is deeply connected to the web of life, and my actions have consequences for everyone around me.
{@b Live and Let Live.} Ideals aren't worth killing or going to war for.
{@b History.} Only through studying the past can we avoid repeating past mistakes.

entries.name: Color Combinations
entries: Adding white to green steers it toward neutral good and gentler notions of community, embodied in characters such as healing druids, bards, or kindly rangers.
Adding blue to green solidifies its neutrality, embodied in archetypes such as the sagacious druid or scholar of nature.

Adding black to green steers it toward neutral evil in the form of sinister druids and stalking rangers. Adding red to green leads to an intense neutral or chaotic neutral, embodied in a totemic barbarian or fierce ranger.
